column4: Hey there, can someone tell me how to remove a file via the terminal
del, remove ?
rm file
force remove doesn't prompt you, directory remove removes a directory, rm -f is a force removal rm -r is a directory removal, or you combine them rm -rf to do a force directory removal
none
if you want to be really cool use "sudo apt-get install program" from the command line and "apt-cache search program" or "apt-cache show program" to search
and no to your other question
you said what was the difference between installing from them, there is no difference between how they install stuff
yeah pretty much, synaptic is a graphical front end for apt-get
don't run them at the same time though
rpm maybe?
rpm is red hat package manager, it is not used in ubuntu and other debian distros, it is used in distros like fedora or suse
it has to do with a different way the program is packaged, ubuntu uses debs and fedora and suse and some of the others use rpms
it reads from the $PATH if you don't specify otherwise
do "echo $PATH" to see where those places are
you specify when you do the ./
yeah that was the line I was talking about
gksudo gedit /etc/environment
sbin is stuff that is essential for the system to run, the really important stuff, bin is less important stuff
I think the official distinction is that sbin is system binaries, and bin is command binaries
how does the /usr/bin different /bin ?
/bin is stuff that is needed in single user mode, /usr/bin is stuff that isn't
same thing, user binaries, usually daemons
